metadata.title: SUBJECT AREAS TITLE Discovery of a divergent HPIV4 from respiratory secretions using second and third generation metagenomic sequencing

body_text.text: Microbial screening -Immunological and PCR based assays All secretions were initially tested for respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) using immunological tests including Immunofluorescence or membrane ELISA. As only 36% of the samples collected in the RSV season tested positive, we additionally tested them for a range of viral and bacterial pathogens (see methods). The full results are available upon request. Briefly, the extensive PCR testing revealed that ~46% of the secretions tested positive for RSV, ~20% for various picornaviruses and smaller proportions of a range of other respiratory pathogens (Supplementary Table S1 ). In 75% of secretions a pathogen was found, where in 20% of the samples more than one pathogen was identified. A summary of detected viral and bacterial pathogens using PCRbased-assays in children with one or multiple infections is listed in Supplementary Table S2 . With the exception HPIV4, all viruses identified using deep sequencing in this study had been previously screened using hybridization-based methods (Supplementary Table S1 ). Despite the increased sensitivity of PCR based assays, these results emphasize the limitations of PCR based identification of microbial pathogens in the public health setting. The largest proportion of humanvirus-sequences identified (61%) was taxonomically classified as HPIV4, with most sequences predominating from one high titer sample. The second largest portion of human-virus-reads derived from human metapneumovirus (hMPV) (19%), which also predominately originated from one specimen. All identified coronavirus sequences were identified as the OC43 strain, accounting for 7% of the sequence reads. Finally, small subsets of reads to four known respiratory viruses were identified in some samples, including influenza A (n=1), human parainfluenza virus 3 (n=1), adenovirus (n=2) and human rhinovirus (n=3), two of which mapped to the recently proposed type C species 9 . Efforts in characterizing the HRV-C genomes are currently ongoing.

In addition to the analysis of sequence reads, contigs were also generated from each sample and classified using BLASTn and BLASTx expectation (E) scores from searches against the entire GenBank, with the highest scoring hit used to assign taxonomy. The assembly of filtered reads generated several contigs, however, few were taxonomically identified as viral (Supplementary   Table S3 ).

Three contigs homologous to hMPV were identified in one sample. Local nucleotide identity to the virus ranged from 97-99% over a minimum alignment of 528-bp, indicating high similarity to known sequence strains. It is unclear why prior PCR screening failed to detect this virus, however, due to the high sequence homology to existing hMPV genomes it was excluded from further analysis.

A number of contigs were also identified as torque teno virus (TTV), a single stranded DNA (ssDNA) virus of the Anelloviridae 10 . TTV and the related anelloviruses are characterized by their significant genetic diversity and high prevalence in human populations. Although extensively studied, evidence for clinical association to disease is still lacking 11 . The contigs identified to TTV homologs had a nucleotide identity ranging from 86-95% to genomes searched. Given the generally high diversity of the viral family, it suggested significant similarity to characterized strains.

having highest homology within the Circoviridae. The contigs had a local amino acid homology ranging between 59-69% (for local alignments covering at least 100 bp) with highest similarity to genomes recently characterized from reclaimed waste-water 12 . Members of the Circoviridae family represent the smallest replicating viral genomes known to infect eukaryotes. They comprise a group of circular ssDNA viruses known to be severely pathogenic in birds and swine 13, 14 . They were recently identified in human plasma and stool 15 ; however, their widespread biological significance remains poorly understood. Lysholm and colleagues also identified various circovirus-like reads, but attributed their presence to reagent-derived extraction kit contamination 5 . The same commercial extraction kit supplier was used in this study (see Methods), and therefore chose to exclude these samples from further analysis. pertussis, N. Pneumoniae, and C. Pneumoniae using PCR assay but resulted in no detection. FIGREF0.text: Paramyxoviridae and the Coronaviridae comprised the largest portions of identified sequences accounting 42% and 7% of the total count respectively (SupplementaryFigure S1). The three other viral families known to cause clinical respiratory infections (Picornaviridae, Orthomyxoviridae and Adenoviridae) were equally represented with 1% of total identified viral sequences.

FIGREF1.text: Pie chart of taxonomic distribution of sequence reads from 92 nasopharyngeal samples sequenced on the GS FLX Titanium. Abbreviationshuman parainfluenza virus 4 (HPIV4), human metapneumovirus (hMPV), human coronavirus OC43 (HCoV-OC43), Influenza A (Influ A), human rhinovirus (HRV), human adenovirus (HAdV).

FIGREF2.text: Maximum likelihood phylogenetic tree from aligned full genomes of human parainfluenza virus 4. The tree was generated using the Generalized time-reversible with invariable sites (GTR+I) nucleotide substitution model with 1000 bootstrap replicates, and midpoint rooted for clarity. Scale bar represents estimated phylogenetic distance. HPIV4 strains are labeled with strain name and GenBank accession number on the right. The reported Danish strain, HPIV4_DK(459), (GenBank accession no. KF483663) is shown in red boldface. Maximum likelihood phylogenetic tree from aligned nucleoprotein gene in human parainfluenza virus 4. The tree was generated using the Tamura-Nei with invariable sites (TrN+I) nucleotide substitution model with 1000 bootstrap replicates, and midpoint rooted for clarity. Scale bar represents estimated phylogenetic distance. HPIV4 strains are labeled with strain name and GenBank accession number on the right. The tree was generated using the Tamura-Nei (TrN) nucleotide substitution model with 1000 bootstrap replicates, and midpoint rooted for clarity. Scale bar represents estimated phylogenetic distance. The tree was generated using the Tamura-Nei (TrN) nucleotide substitution model with 1000 bootstrap replicates, and midpoint rooted for clarity. Scale bar represents estimated phylogenetic distance. HPIV4 strains are labeled with strain name and GenBank accession number on the right. The reported Danish strain, HPIV4_DK(459), (GenBank accession no. KF483663) is shown in red boldface. Maximum likelihood phylogenetic tree from aligned fusion gene in human parainfluenza virus 4. The tree was generated using the HKY+I nucleotide substitution model with 1000 bootstrap replicates, and midpoint rooted for clarity. Scale bar represents estimated phylogenetic distance. HPIV4 strains are labeled with strain name and GenBank accession number on the right. The reported Danish strain, HPIV4_DK(459), (GenBank accession no. KF483663) is shown in red boldface. Maximum likelihood phylogenetic tree from aligned hemagglutinin-neuraminidase gene in human parainfluenza virus 4. The tree was generated using the Tamura-Nei (TrN+G) nucleotide substitution model with a discrete gamma distribution with 6 rate categories, 1000 bootstrap replicates, and midpoint rooted for clarity. Scale bar represents estimated phylogenetic distance. HPIV4 strains are labeled with strain name and GenBank accession number on the right. TABREF0.text: Results of PCR assays for common respiratory pathogens of 500 consecutive (hospitalized) children

TABREF1.text: Prevalence of common pathogens identified using PCR diagnostics in 500 consecutive children with upper and lower respiratory tract infections.Supplementary Table S1). In order to fill the diagnostic gap, 92 'negative' nasopharyngeal or tracheal specimens were processed further, using an in-house metagenomic high-throughput sequencing pipeline for viral detection. The specimens were initially enriched for viral particles using a combination of nuclease treatment and filtration, and then amplified using random RT-PCR-based amplification 1, 2 . Pooled pyrosequenced PCR products generated a total of 851,591 sequence reads with an average read length of 229 nucleotides (nt). In order to reduce the complexity of the metagenomic data, all recovered sequences were filtered using BLAT sequence similarity searches to local ribosomal and human databases, in effect leaving 424,488 sequence reads (49.8%) for further analysis. The taxonomic identification of viral sequences followed, with all filtered reads being mapped to the European Bioinformatic Institute's (EBI) database of virus and phage genomes. An overview of the recovered viral sequences can be seen in SupplementaryFigure S1.A total of 58% of viral reads were taxonomically identified to be associated with infections in humans, with approximately 19% and 21% of the remaining sequences being classified as either 'phage' or 'other' respectively. The majority of the reads within the 'other' category were identified as viruses infecting invertebrates and plants. We postulate that these sequences derive from either trace contamination (most likely from sampling or laboratory reagents) or taxonomically ambiguous identification of low complexity regions, as various other studies have reported similar findings[3][4][5] . Interestingly, a number of low abundance reads were identified as Mimiviridae-like sequences in four respiratory samples. Mimivirus is currently one of the largest viruses discovered, and infects the free-living amoeba Acanthamoeba polyphaga. Its status and role as a

TABREF2.text: Identified contigs from GS FLX Titanium screening of 92 nasopharyngeal specimens. The total number of reads identified from the sample. The number of reads following filtration of ribosomal and human sequences. The fraction of reads remaining after filtration. Number of assembled contigs greater than 500 nucleotides in length. The fraction of filtered reads in contigs. Contigs with homolgy match to other. Contigs with no known homolog match when searched on GenBanks non-redundant database using BLASTn and BLASTxNumber of patients infected with HPIV4_DK and co-infections with other viruses.Curiously, four samples that were pyrosequenced tested positive for HPIV4 only using the realtime assay, indicating that the GS FLX sequencing was not as sensitive as the PCR assay. A summary of samples positive for HPIV4 using the real-time PCR assay (SupplementaryTable S4) indicates that the virus was detected alone as well as in co-infections with other viruses. Two children positive for HPIV4 were also infected with three other viral pathogens known to cause upper and/or lower respiratory tract infections. All hospitalized children infected with HPIV4 were having an uncomplicated course of infection, with none requiring artificial ventilation. Inpatient care lasted up to three days and no deaths occurred during hospitalization.
